conclusion: Understand the flow of liquid through the baffles to determine which container (E or F) the liquid will flow into.
Baffles are designed to redirect the flow of the liquid, and the direction of the liquid flow can be inferred from the orientation of the baffles.
Baffle A is oriented horizontally.
Baffle B is oriented diagonally.
Baffle C is oriented vertically.
Baffle D is oriented horizontally.
For Baffle A (horizontal), the liquid will flow in a horizontal direction.
For Baffle B (diagonal), the liquid will flow in a diagonal direction.
For Baffle C (vertical), the liquid will flow in a vertical direction.
For Baffle D (horizontal), the liquid will flow in a horizontal direction.
If the liquid flows from A, it will be redirected by the horizontal baffle and then by the diagonal baffle B.
The exact path will depend on the specific orientation and the exit point of the baffle.
If the liquid flows from B, it will be redirected by the diagonal baffle and then by the vertical baffle C.
The exact path will depend on the specific orientation and the exit point of the baffle.
If the liquid flows from C, it will be redirected by the vertical baffle and then by the horizontal baffle D.
The exact path will depend on the specific orientation and the exit point of the baffle.
If the liquid flows from D, it will be redirected by the horizontal baffle and then by the diagonal baffle B.
The exact path will depend on the specific orientation and the exit point of the baffle.
The liquid will eventually flow into either container E or F.
The exact container will depend on the specific path the liquid takes through the baffles.
By analyzing the paths and the orientation of the baffles, the liquid will ultimately flow into container F.
The liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and will flow into container F.
